content.question:
<math alttext="2 H I gas is in equilibrium with H 2 gas plus I 2 gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>HI</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mo>⇄</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>

Substance 

Initial Concentration (<math alttext="molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>) 

Equilibrium Concentration (<math alttext="molar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>) 

<math alttext="H I" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HI</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> 
0.30 
0.24 

<math alttext="H 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> 
0.00 
0.030 

<math alttext="I 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> 
0.00 
? 

In an experiment involving the reaction shown above, a sample of pure <math alttext="H I" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HI</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> was placed inside a rigid container at a certain temperature. The table above provides the initial and equilibrium concentrations for some of the substances in the reaction. Based on the data, which of the following is the value of the equilibrium constant (<math alttext="K sub e q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>) for the reaction, and why?

choices.label: <math alttext="K sub e q equals 2.5 times 10 to the negative 1 power" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>2.5</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>, because <math alttext="the equilibrium molar concentration of I 2 equals 2 times the equilibrium molar concentration of H I" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>[</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>×</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>[HI</mtext><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

<math alttext="K sub e q equals 6.3 times 10 to the negative 2 power" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>6.3</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>, because <math alttext="the equilibrium molar concentration of I 2 is equal to one half the equilibrium molar concentration of H I" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>[</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac><msub><mrow><mtext>[HI</mtext><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

<math alttext="K sub e q equals 1.6 times 10 to the negative 2 power" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>1.6</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>, because <math alttext="the equilibrium molar concentration of I 2 equals 2 times the equilibrium molar concentration of H 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>[</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>[</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

<math alttext="K sub e q equals 3.1 times 10 to the negative 2 power" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>3.1</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>, because <math alttext="the equilibrium molar concentration of I 2 is equal to 2 times the equilibrium molar concentration of H 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>[</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>×</mo><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>[</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

content.answer: <math alttext="K sub e q equals 1.6 times 10 to the negative 2 power" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>1.6</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>, because <math alttext="the equilibrium molar concentration of I 2 equals 2 times the equilibrium molar concentration of H 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>[</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>[</mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>q</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

skill.text: 5.C: Explain the relationship between variables within an equation when one variable changes.
